info.title: getting started
info.text: In this example I'll demonstrate just a few ways you can use the transform property.

info.title: HTML elements
info.text: In our HTML we have a stack of divs each with their corresponding number in them, and a few with specific classes applied to them.

info.title: CSS rules
info.text: Up in our CSS, we have a CSS rule applied to all the divs which changes their background color, their default width and height as well as centers their text and adds a bit of margin around them.

info.title: transform: translate
info.text: Our "red" class uses the transform property to change the placement of this div. It does this by using the CSS translate() function which takes two arguments separated by a comma. First, how much to nudge the div from the left of it's original position or it's "x" value, and second how much to shift it down, or it's "y" value.

info.title: relative behavior
info.text: The space that this div originally occupied remains intact, which is why we see the div sized gab between divs 1 and 3. This is similar to how "relative" positioning works, as explained in the basic positioning example.

info.title: transform: rotate
info.text: The "blue" class uses the transform property yet again, except rather than passing the translate() function as its value, it uses the CSS rotate function to turn our div 30deg, or 30 degrees clock-wise.

info.title: other transform functions
info.text: These transform functions can be combined, notice how in the "green" class (you may need to scroll a big on the page to see it) we're using the translate() function yet again, this time along side the scale() function, used to resize the div (in this case making it smaller), and the skew() function used to distort the div.

info.title: in closing
info.text: There's loads more you can do with the CSS transform property, including move elements in 3D space. Check out this example for how to set up 3D transforms.
